ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot of basic Russian grammar that I had not known before, which was very helpful. I started to improve my formal Russian writing, though I am still working on that -- it was very helpful to learn formal phrases and ways of writing. I practiced reading Russian literature as well, and discussing it in class.
A better understanding of Russian literature, syntax, and grammar.
I developed my speaking, reading and writing skills and learned some grammar.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The students in this course had a wide variety of Russian skills and knowledge before joining the class. As someone who had not practiced Russian as much as my peers, it was definitely hard for me to catch up and stay on top of my work, because things like reading and writing took a lot longer for me. Looking back, I feel like I was in the wrong course because my skills were not up to par with some of my other classmates, who were almost fluent. I'm not sure what the plans for the Russian heritage/bilingual program are, but I think it would be great if next time, people could be split up into more levels. There were some students in the class who were basically fluent, and could have been in another heritage class. Then, there were some students, like myself, who needed to go a bit slower in order to really learn the language. Splitting up these two groups could really help everyone. I'm not sure if this is possible with the size of the Russian heritage program, but it is something to consider anyway.

The course is outstanding for students with a firm grasp of the Russian language who want to improve their performance and understanding. It offers a great mix of fundamental exercises and classical readings.

This was a great course. We developed a variety of language skills and it was really helpful to have conversations. I think more readings on contemporary culture, events and literature in Russia would have been interesting.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: A wonderful course for native/bilingual Russian speakers of all levels (although it would be very helpful to take the first semester before this). Prof. Titus manages to adjust the work to perfectly fit every individual student and their abilities.

I would recommend this class to a bilingual student who is almost fluent in Russian. I wouldn't recommend this class to someone who comes from a Russian-speaking family but hasn't had a lot of practice with the language themselves.
Absolutely! This course is well paced and thoroughly enjoyable.
This is a great course if you want to keep up and improve your Russian with a very light workload.
